commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Just about anything on a string  (3)(3)
2. Bills first introduced in 1861  (5)
3. Generate clippings, say  (3)
4. Extremely rare, facetiously  (5)(6)
5. Timer setting  (4)


CAT TOY
FIVES
MOW
STILL MOOING
OVEN
Soon, you'll have to replace PENN with
That‚Äôs not a foot, a foot has 5 of them though.
ADZE in a Monday puzzle? No fair!

A perfect, no STRESS puzzle, with a clever theme that doesn‚Äôt get any tighter than this. 

The highlight for me is the wonderful debut of PERSNICKETY.  What a great word! I like CAJOLES too. 

Congratulations on your debut, Suzanne. Well done!
This one felt really tough for a Monday. A holiday week Monday, no less üòâ

A charming, lightly challenging puzzle, perfect for a cold day by the fireside (well, GAS heater, if you're PERSNICKETY). I  definitely did not want to be OUTRAGED, or ONATEAR, just GENTLY entertained, which I was.

Thank you, Suzanne, for giving us your breaks. Come by anytime.
I get most of the themes, but what coin is PENN short for?
Could've had a more musical SW corner with different clues for OIL and LED (midnight, zeppelin)
Nice job, Suzanne. I hope your thesis will be as tight as the theme of this puzzle (albeit in a few more words).
This is my favourite Monday puzzle ever! What a fun and thoughtful theme. I hope we get a lot more puzzles from this constructor!
I loved this puzzle! A perfect Monday with a clever theme, I hope to see more from Suzanne in the future!
The best Monday puzzle! 10/10 theme. Congrats on the debut!!

POPO for police? I've not heard that one. This is what it brings to mind: Pat him on the POPO and watch him laugh! Wondering where it came from, even though I did say that to my kids, I found this!: https://youtu.be/vjNdjmzbDQU?si=uY6hoobLlBu7r241 I had no idea it WAS a song, and it DID make me laugh, though no POPO was involved.

> Will our children and children‚Äôs children know about MOZILLA, the [Creator of Firefox and Thunderbird]? Crosswords may be the only thing keeping its history alive.

Oof, that one stung. Firefox isn't exactly Netscape, are people so deep in the Chrome hole that they forgot other browsers exist?

When I was younger, I always carried a wallet with a change compartment. For men, these were hard to find; most guys carried change loose in their pants pocket.  But I was always able to find one when it was time to replace the wallet.

I was solicited for credit cards when I was finishing college, and I no longer needed to worry that the meal I was eating was going to cost more than I had in my pocket.

As time passed, I started using credit cards to pay for most everyday expenses, and started accumulating points or miles or got cash back. I used cash less and less, to the point where I could get $100 at the ATM at the beginning of the month, and still have $95 at the end of the month.

I even started paying for small items, like candy bars, with credit cards.

In the end, I was mostly using bills for tips, and found I wasn't using coins at all.

Occasionally, I'd find myself at a place that was cash only, but where I live, such places are fortunately few and far between.

On such occasions, I sometimes found myself with coins back as change. I literally didn't know what to do with them. I put them down on my dresser, and there they sat.

So the demise of the penny seems long overdue; the nickel should be next. Neither of them buys anything anymore; we could just drop one decimal place if we wanted to keep them, but then there'd be fewer millionaires.

My current wallet has no changepurse. Just a lot of card slots.

If international change was allowed, QUADRUPED would have made a nice answer.




Et tu, emu.

Suzanne, if this was your debut we need to see a lot more from you! One of the best Mondays I can remember‚Äîwho says that just because Mondays need to be accessible, they can‚Äôt still have sparkling fill, clever clues and and a stellar theme you won‚Äôt guess ahead of time? Loved the clue for BIG LEAD. You certainly didn‚Äôt blow it on this puzzle.
May your dissertation be so successful as this puzzle!
A Monday that felt closer to a Tuesday is always welcome
Nice Monday puzzle, loved the theme! Congrats on the solid debut!!!!!

This was a phenomenal debut. I‚Äôm seriously impressed. I was engaged throughout the fill and I loved the theme. I still use Firefox as my browser ü§ì For the longest time, it was the only one that had a private browsing option. I do use Safari and Chrome on occasion, but my go to is Firefox for now. My husband also uses Firefox ü§∑üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è As for JAZZ QUARTETs, I thought I‚Äôd share one of my favorites. Wynton Marsalis spoke at Princeton in 1994 at the Baccalaureate service during graduation week, which I had the pleasure of attending when my sister graduated from there. Such a talented family of musicians! https://youtu.be/HLD8i8CMw14?si=7Bc1PLVErNNn4KOh Enjoy üòä

"I was going to pay in coins. Should I change?"
"Well, money you should ask..."

(Sounds like a cents-ible conversation.)
This was a really fun puzzle. A perfect Monday!
Excellent Monday puzzle. Clever and fresh.  Thank you Suzanne!

Very nice puzzle. 

Super many thanks

Re: the Constructor Notes and 52A, I had a friend in college who had a beautiful long-haired calico cat that she doted on. The friend was looking for a name for her home-based typing service. I suggested

PURRSNICKETY but she didn't like it.

Ditto, my second suggestion: PURRFECTION.

You can't please everyone.

cheeky monday and excellent debut.
i wonder if anyones first seven puzzles have ever appeared in sequence from monday to sunday...
I love that Suzanne‚Äôs sisters chimed in shortly after the puzzle dropped!! Hi Blake and Jacki üëãüèº
Two toddlers so far and TOOTSY has yet to be uttered! Failing as a parent, too busy thinking AUDAL was a word.

I was TESTY about yesterday‚Äôs puzzle but today I was ONATEAR. Monday is always EASY enough to make regular solvers feel like JEDIMASTERS. 

I did my usual challenge (using the across clues only, no peeking at the down clues) and I managed it in 13:05. A nice way to make the puzzle a little crunchier and to make it last a little longer at the start of the week. 

Frankly I‚Äôm glad I didn‚Äôt have to solve POPFOUL or SEQ. And not to be too PERSNICKETY, I was under the impression that TOOTSY meant a tiny toe, not a tiny foot.
I always thought tootsies were toes. ü§∑üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

Late to posting, but loved the puzzle.  Fast & fun. 
I was surprised when I finished and it congratulated me on my streak. I thought I was doing a bonus, and it was only 5pm! 
The puzzle usually drops @7pm. 
Very puzzled.
Well, a theme can't get much tighter than this.  Congratulations on your first NYT puzzle, Suzanne.  Hopefully you'll be back again and again.
Fun puzzle but I never heard of POPO; that's a new one on me.

I'm wide awake, so no excuses, but maybe it's the lack of coffee, or 18 hours on the road yesterday, but I struggled with this one. More than doubled my Monday average.  Very nice puzzle and congrats on your first!
much more enjoyable than sundays (i hate a rebus)

A brief history of SHORTCHANGE as a Crosslandia revealer.

It‚Äôs been used twice before, but never as in today‚Äôs puzzle, and never in the Times.  In one puzzle, the last words of theme phrases were anagrams of synonyms for ‚Äúshort‚Äù, such as EXTRA MALLS.

In the other, anagrams of ‚Äúshort‚Äù were circled and embedded in theme phrases, such as GIF(T)(H)(O)(R)(S)E.

The end.

I liked today‚Äôs version best of the three.  I reacted to those above with an, ‚ÄúOh, I see‚Äù.  Whereas today‚Äôs gave me a fist-pump ‚ÄúHah!‚Äù.

I also liked: 
‚Ä¢	LOW in today‚Äôs grid echoing ‚Äúshort‚Äù.  
‚Ä¢	Semordnilaps LEE and EEL cohabitating the box.  
‚Ä¢	How PERSNIKETY and CAJOLES, beautified the grid as the Scrabbly JAZZ QUARTET sparked it up. 
‚Ä¢	And, on a ONA note, ON A DIET, ON A TEAR, and nONAgon.

I love how your mind saw ‚Äúshortchange‚Äù, Suzanne, and morphed it into this theme.  That whets my appetite for more from you ‚Äì and may there be!  Congratulations on your debut, and thank you for a splendid outing.

Lovely Monday puzzle!

After the second theme answer, I though for sure the revealer would be SPARE CHANGE, which would have also worked, though not as well and probably not for a Monday. I was quickly disabused of that when I filled in 60D. PUE definitely would not have worked!

Kudos all around.
To Suzanne for her debut puzzle
To Sam for the column and the photo chosen to head the column
And to the photographer for the amazing photo

There's always discussion about POPO when it turns up.
I first heard it used on The Wire way back in 2002, so don't have any problem with it appearing in a puzzle. The first time it showed up was in 2014.
Could someone help me understand the connection between ‚Äúdon‚Äôt blow it‚Äù and big lead? üßê

Really fun Monday. Fairly smooth solve, but it wasn't until I was almost done and stopped and pondered that I finally caught on to the theme. That's always a nice touch. Looking forward to more from Ms. Oliver. A couple of fun puzzle finds today - the first one inspired by TOOTSY. A Thursday from February 19, 1998 by A.J. Santora. Five theme answers in that one: TEETERTOTTERED TAKESTWOTOTANGO TICTACTOE TOOTTOOTTOOTSIE TURNSTHETABLES Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/19/1998&g=56&d=A I'll put the other puzzle in a reply. ...

First we lose the mighty PENN
A coin once stubborn as a JENN
Next to go will be the NICKE
Which has slowed down to a TRICKE
Followed by the mighty DIM
Certainly, it‚Äôs past its PRIM
Sadly, next will be the QUARTE
I‚Äôll drown my sorrows in a PORTE
I guess I find it very STRANG
To have to say goodbye to CHANG

Congratulations on a fantastic NYT puzzle debut, Ms Oliver!

I keep an ever-growing list of words I‚Äôve learned from crosswords, Spelling Bee and other puzzles and games. I don‚Äôt often learn a new word from a Monday puzzle. PERSNICKETY is not new to me, but Today I Learned that it means ‚Äúfastidious‚Äù and not ‚Äúcrotchety‚Äù or ‚Äúpeevish.‚Äù (David Connell, if you‚Äôre out there: I too often ignore your advice to look up the words that I think I know. But I‚Äôm getting better about doing that.)

I expect to have plenty of opportunities to use PERSNICKETY. It is fun to say and both my husband and I are PERSNICKETY about some things. (Unfortunately, they‚Äôre not the same things.)

Thanks for the fun!
Finished up yesterday's puzzle last night, which was great BTW, and then this was a proper dessert.  Congrats on the debut and hope to see more.

Ah, PERSNICKETY, a lovely old word.
Wasn't it used to describe Eloise of the Plaza Hotel? I guess that's old-fashioned, too.

A fun and lively puzzle, Suzanne, thanks.
Cops, slangily=POPO?
What a delightful puzzle. Thanks, Suzanne! Happy Monday, y‚Äôall! Peace!
That's it! I'm keeping an index card with the names of every rapper that shows up. That particular musical  made-up-word genre is the Lord's gift to crossword puzzle makers. üòõ

I ran POP FOUL past DHubby, who made his "That's NOT right face."  POP UP or FOUL BALL ....or FOUL OUT, because that's usually fatal.  The catcher jumps up, throwing off his mask, and gets under the ball as it--fatally--drops into his waiting glove.  YER OUT!

I try not to be PERSNICKETY, but I spell it PERSNICK i TY.

Most definitely needed The Reveal to get the puzzle.  I also got led astray (OPEN BOOK; JEDI KNIGHTS; JAZZ BANDoops).  
Wonderful start to the week, though.  More, please.
That was hard for a Monday, at least for me! Very fun, thank you.

I usually whizz through on Mondays but the SW corner defeated me today. I'd never heard of POPO, ON A TEAR or POP FOUL and thought TOOTSY was a toe rather than a foot. I didn't know PERNICKETY could be spelt with an S in it either, so that baffled me for a while. Oh well, we live and learn!
Small, not SHORT, but still‚Ä¶ https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=CLLjLiND8rE

Congratulations on an excellent debut!
Loved the revealer.
Looking forward to seeing many more puzzles from you.
Great debut Suzanne, even if you did make my Monday average a little worse, grrr.
Zipped through this fun and cute debut. Thanks Suzanne

(In my opinion) to difficult for a Monday and a really sloppy theme‚Ä¶ A Pun is generally joke on a word that sounds like a word or has different meanings. Not a partial word with letters missing. I get the fact that it said SHORT change, but if you added the letter that was shorted, then it isn‚Äôt a pun at all. It is the word‚Ä¶
I hate to be pernickety but it‚Äôs pernickety not persnickety

One more puzzle find - a Tuesday from June 29, 2021 by Alan Arbesfeld. First theme clue and answer: "Toy with a spring, literally." THEJACKBOX Same trick with each of the other theme answers: THENIPBUD THEBEWAY THEUPAIR THEPIESKY THEBACKDAY Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=6/29/2021&g=55&d=A ...
Lower left a bit left field for a Monday. The rest was fine.
What a fantastic debute! Lots of fun clues with a very clever revealer. I hope to see more puzzles from Suzanne, this was my favorite Monday crossword yet!
Got it in one pass through the across clues and one pass through the downs. Still not fast enough for a record, but definitely faster than usual. Fun puzzle!
Thank you to Sargento Cheese for keeping PERSNICKETY in the language. (I had no idea that the Brits drop the S from that word, interesting.)
Great debut! Congrats, Suzanne! More please.
Nice breezy puzzle.  I especially likes 52a... I wonder how many times this word as appeared in the past.

Thank you for a fine and clever debut, Suzanne!  Best of luck to you as you complete grad school. I feel WISER having completed your grid and not the least bit SHORTCHANGEd -- I hope we'll be seeing more from you!
Respectfully disagree.  One of the best things about crossword puzzles is learning new words.

Delightful. 
The PERNICKETY difference has been addressed already. Scots dialect has the word "perjink", which has the same meaning. 

I know ADZE from many UK crosswords. We all need words with Z in them. 

My niece in Elon, North Carolina has a local bookshop called Persnickety Books.
Price of admission was just a bit steep for newbies on a Monday...nevertheless, a clever and fun puzzle! Thsnks Suzanne! more please!

Congratulations on your fun debut puzzle, Suzanne!!  I thoroughly enjoyed your Monday challenge, even if I did have to flyspeck to find my silly error to earn my gold star.  I found the theme quite funny and picked up on it rather quickly, even before I read the Wordplay column.  Thanks for the humor, fun entries, and smooth ease into the week.  Here's to your next puzzle!!
The theme today was really cute! Great debut, I really enjoyed it!
Why was my comment yesterday suggesting people check out the holiday-themed puzzle in the Boston Globe removed?
Pretty cute! I told my boss I was feeling ISLE yesterday. He looked at me funny. That was strange. He don't know English?
This was such a fun puzzle, I loved the theme! Congratulations on the debut Suzanne, I hope to see more of your puzzles in the future!

As a longtime user of MOZILLA Firefox and Thunderbird, columnist Sam's comment on their durability is sobering to me, though likely unintentionally so on her part. The company is currently facing some heated criticism from users like myself on their plans to (further) integrate AI tools into Firefox. The future remains to be seen...

(FWIW, I'm a 1970 baby; I've witnessed the entire history of web browsers and email clients.)

I was really excited when I saw the clue of a four letter word for the police.

I immediately entered FUZZ, which I have heard for a long time.  I was really stoked to have two words containing a Z, one as the first letter.

Alas, it was not meant to be.  I guess "fuzz" is too far back in the dawn of creation.

Great debut puzzle from you, Suzanne Oliver and  I look forward to more from you. It was a very clever theme. I was quite surprised to hear from you that PERSNICKETY was a debut word too. I‚Äôve definitely used it and heard it used. Hope to see your work again soon.
People say I can be pretty persnickety myself, but I enjoyed this puzzle very much. (A relief after Sunday's tough one.)
I think 67 across also works if it ends with an E (and it's punnier)
Your JAZZQUARTET is missing a drumset!
Nice, after a 2 hour stint yesterday; but I question that COMAS are deep sleeps.

OPEN NOTES was a new one for me (we used to have OPEN BOOK tests sometimes in college) 

But a fun Monday kind of solve ,and all welcomes to our new setter!
Yet another CWP that is much difficult than it's supposed to be based on the day posted. Wondering why I am subscribed when the quality and enjoyment of these puzzles seem to be dwindling.

Since it seems to be a hot topic in the comments I'll throw in one from left field and mention that Tootsies are teeth in my house, and the kids have Toesies, but Tootsy for a foot is new to me.

Good puzzle today, although whatever Breyers and their competitors do was a blocker. I (not very cleverly) thought that you should not blow a BigLeaf, never thought beyond that even though I wasn't very confident about it when I typed it in. I didn't have the trivia answer to tell me I was wrong, so all the time I spent trying to figure out how I'd ended up with Popo and trying to rearrange that section into something that had a real word was down the drain. 
I've heard both Persnickety and Pernickety, so no complaints there. I thought it was well put together in general.

Tootsies are teeth in my house. The kids all had Toesies too.
Enjoyed this puzzle, it felt well put together, even though I got cooked by Breyers competitor. Spent ages trying to find an alternative fit to get rid of Popo (seemed too ridiculous to be an answer). Turned out my mistake was not blowing a big leaf instead of big lead. Whatever Breyers or their competition does has never made it across the Atlantic so I had no inclination that I‚Äôd used a pretty stupid answer for the big lead.
At least the Pats made up for blowing a BIGLEAD 2 weeks ago by coming back last night

I liked this Monday puzzle.

Stumbled slightly on OPENbookS and JEDIknightS, but that was quickly rectified with the crosses. Excellent entry with PERSNICKETY.
Alas, I didn't get the theme until after the puzzle was complete, and then had a good chuckle.

another unnecessary theme based on a bad pun. 

i don‚Äôt understand why themes are so popular. i generally solve most puzzles without regard to them and most rarely add much.

the puzzle was good otherwise
I have never heard of the word POPO. Does anybody actually use it?  And a tootsie is a toe, not a whole foot.
To me tootsies have always been toes ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

Can anyone explain ‚Äôanil‚Äô from yesterday? I thought it was outside seeds, like strawberries have, but the hint had to do with blue dye? I loved the theme!

today‚Äôs puzzle made me miss pennies. hope they come back one day.

My favorite encore clues from last week:

Person in hot pants?  (4)
Appropriate inappropriately  (5)


LIAR
USURP
@Steve L Ah, short changed at the source!
@Steve L USMIN? AMERICANPEOPL?
@Calig Seconded.
@Joy Harkin. ADZE is to woodworking as ‚ÄúOreo‚Äù is to cookies, at least in NYT xwords

@Gabe

The one just discontinued

@Steve L
Getting centimental already?

@Al  in Pittsburgh
Well, that's appalling. It seems that the Republicans have a much longer history of erasure than I suspected. üò†

@Al  in Pittsburgh

That doesn't surprise me at all about Safire.

I think I heard somewhere that Norway, maybe, used a smallest denomination that was roughly our quarter.

I could be wrong about that.  But I don't think I'm wrong that inflation, which to some extent is natural and even desirable, will eventually eliminate the need for the smallest denominations.

I was in Italy in the late 70s, when they still had the lira.  I don't think any token or bill represented a single lira.  Almost any normal purchase was in the thousands of lira, usually tens of thousands.

@Al  in Pittsburgh

I'd really like to comment on how people like Jimmy Carter have been treated, but I'm sure it would bring down the wrath of those who come her for people unlike myself.

@Francis
Years ago before there were Euros, I traveled through Europe with Mom.  Our goal was to collect one of each coin for each country.  The hardest (and smallest) was a 10 Lira piece.  Worth about half a cent at the time.

@Francis
Go for it.

@Francis
I'm not a numismatist but I'm given to understand that one of its fascinations is the fresh understanding of history that it provides. This makes Safire's idea even more reprehensible.
@Gabe  I'd throw my two cents in, but you only need half of that to answer your question.

Lily,
Welcome to the NYT Crossword. I assume you're new here ... or you just missed POPO on June 29th.

@Lily

If you‚Äôre wondering if it‚Äôs just crosswordese, my (adult) daughter actually uses it and I learned it from her before seeing it in a puzzle‚Äîso it‚Äôs a real thing
@Lily maybe it's a West Coast thing (West Side)
@Lily me neither. Popo is Spanish for poop. Not sure if connected.
@mkrl I still use Firefox!!

@Jacqui J
I use DuckDuckGo for many reasons, not the least the adorableness of its name and the availability of a no-AI setting for its browser.

@mkrl

I went Chrome for a while, but privacy concerns sent me back to Firefox. I hope it‚Äôs not going anywhere.

@mkrl
I use both Chrome & Firefox (when the Chrome AI drives me to distraction).  Netscape was my browser of choice, and somewhere I have the disks for vers 1-4.

@SBKüïØÔ∏èüïØÔ∏èüïØÔ∏èüïØÔ∏èüïØÔ∏èüïØÔ∏èüïØÔ∏èüïØÔ∏è
I use DuckDuckGo for searches, but I didn't know they had a browser. I've been using Firefox since they started, as I replied to Jaqui's later post, but am getting totally fed up with it. And there's no one to talk to for the problems I'm having.

@Linda Jo

I have an AOL email account, and people think I'm a dinosaur.

@Steve L

Unless you have bad credit and can‚Äôt get a card, it‚Äôs silly not to substitute every possible cash transaction with a no-fee, cash-back credit card. Pay in full every month and you‚Äôre earning money.

@Steve L the high school that my two youngest kids attended went cashless in 2021, partly because of Covid and people complaining about not wanting to touch cash that was covered with germs. So the snack bar only accepts debit/credit cards. Will we become a completely cashless society at some point??

@Heidi

As long as we don't care that we leave a trail of every transaction we make and our whereabouts whenever we use a card.

@Heidi

Earning twice - once for the cash-back, + more for the interest-free loan (cash earns about 4% during the month before paying the bill)

@Steve L
I still have almost all of the $200 I took from the ATM right before Covid started. Not kidding. I stopped using cash a long time ago. But now a lot of merchants and service people have started adding on a 3% charge for using a credit card. They even did it to my daughter's debit card, which is illegal. Really ticks me off, since they can deduct those fees as a cost of doing business. Just a sneaky price hike. I'd love to boycott those businesses, but at least here, it's getting to be more and more difficult.

Times Rita,
They can deduct those fees as a cost of doing business just as they can deduct the cost what they buy wholesale to sell to you retail as a cost of doing business. They still have to pay the fees!

@Steve L

Never mind coins, looks like the personal check is the next thing to become obsolete. (1 of 48 (2%) monthly payments in 2024)

@Bill in Yokohama

Personal checks have been phased out in many industrialized countries:

Countries That Have Phased Out or Heavily Restricted Checks
Finland: Stopped issuing checks in 1993.
The Netherlands: Banned domestic checks in 2002 and stopped processing foreign checks around 2021.
Denmark: Officially ended the use of checks at the start of 2017.

Regions with Near-Extinct Usage
Western Europe: Checks are rarely used in Belgium, Switzerland, and Germany.
UK: While a 2018 phase-out plan was reversed due to backlash, usage has plummeted to almost zero, with many retailers no longer accepting them. 
Exceptions
United States: Remains one of the last major economies heavily using checks, though usage is declining (11.2 billion in 2021, down from 18.1 billion in 2015).
France: Accounts for the majority (approx. 71% in 2013) of remaining check usage within the European Union. 

(Thanks, Google.)
Poland: Eliminated checks in 2006.
Sweden: Significantly reduced usage through fees and promotion of alternative payments.
New Zealand: Banks stopped processing checks in July 2021.
Australia: The check system is currently being phased out, with a deadline to stop issuance by June 30, 2028, and acceptance by September 30, 2029.
China, South Korea, and Japan: These nations largely skipped the widespread use of personal checks, moving directly from cash-based to electronic payments.

@Steve L

That‚Äôs interesting data.Thanks for sharing it. 

We moved up here over a year ago. I still haven‚Äôt opened an account at a local bank. I‚Äôm too lazy to notify the people who either directly deposit our pensions or automatically debit our accounts for monthly bills. 

We have no trouble using our debit cards from our Austin credit union. The only checks I regularly write anymore are to the person who cleans our house. 

The only downside is that ATM withdrawals are expensive. But who wants cash (besides Almin Pittsburgh)?

@Steve L

One of my health care providers charges me a six-percent fee if I use a credit card--so I write a check when possible.

@lucky13

Ask them if they do Venmo or Zelle.

@Steve L We go to Deer Isle, Maine for a month every summer, where we've been surprised at how many sellers of various things prefer checks.  We have to keep checkbooks on our packing list to remember to bring them.
... quadRUPEd

@Jacqui J
I thought I was the only one who still uses Firefox. But lately I've been having so much trouble accessing sites, such as financial accounts or ones on which I want to make a charitable contribution, that I'm seriously thinking of having to abandon it. It would be horrible after having it as my default since its inception. I don't have these problems on Chrome or Edge. You aren't experiencing this?
@Times Rita every once in a while there is a website that doesn‚Äôt like my browser and I need to use Safari or Chrome, but for the most part, I‚Äôm still team Firefox
@Mike try not to get too centimental üòâ

@Mike

Not to mention, if you buy dinar in another country, you have to peso much. It‚Äôs enough to make you go loonie.

@Mike
Guess now I'll have to offer people a nickel for their thoughts.  Talk about inflation.
@Mike I routinely gripe about the quality of your jokes but I find today‚Äôs set of puns to be indollarable
@dutchiris Sigh. First it was Pluto. Now it's the penny that dropped

@Ms. Billie M. Spaight
Don't talk non-cents.

@Mike
I like the way you always manage to mint something that bears currency to the day's puzzle.  I bank on it.  And your posts are right here -- they not far things!

@lucky13
Well, that cat probably never lifted a paw to assist with the work, you know.
Not yet.  Andrew Ries is the only constructor to hit the cycle in their first seven puzzles, and his weren't in daily order.

@Lewis

somehow i knew youd know‚Ä¶

@Matt
XwordInfo is the source of much trivia as well as photos of our constructors--or most of them, anyway.

@Mean Old Lady

You say ‚Äútrivia,‚Äù I say ‚Äúinteresting and useful information.‚Äù

 I urge anyone who visits that site and enjoys what Jim Horne does to subscribe at whatever level fits your budget. I would hate to see that site go under because Jim can‚Äôt afford to pay for the server space. 

Plus Jim seems like a nice guy. He‚Äôs always been quick to respond when I‚Äôve had a question or comment about a puzzle.

@Eric Hougland
Hmm , well I don't at all think of the site as trivial, but the info is not necessary to the solve.  I don't think trivia is bad!

@Petrol for crunchiness you can try printing it out and solving without using a writing implement. üòÄ

Well, a BIG LEAD is something you might have in a contest of some kind.  Don't blow it is a warning to not do anything that will cause you to lose your lead. It is a bit of a leap to make from the clue to the fill.

@Ciebe

I always find this clue style a bit tricky. Note the lack of quotation marks, whereas 21A and 34D are similarly exclamations but with quote marks.

If 11D had been clued in quotes, the answer would be a rough synonym, perhaps PLAY IT SAFE

Without the quotes, you're looking for something that shouldn't be blown / should be protected.
Amen, MOL. "Don't blow it" may be an idiom, but it's not a pun.

@Tony, Ciebe

There's no question mark, but rather an exclamation mark.  This makes a big difference.

Clues ending in ="it!" occasionally mean that the answer tells you want "it" is.  For example, [Darn it!] might lead to SOCK.  [Blow it!] has clued SMOKE RING.  [Book it!] has clued RESERVED SEAT.

You've got to be careful; usually the phrase just clues an equivalency, so [Darn it!] has also clued OH RATS, NUTS, DRAT, and the like.

This worked in my favour a few times.
A guy on marketplace listed a soundbar for 600ish dollars. I asked if he would take all the cash in my wallet instead, which was 420$
On another occasion, we had hired a handyman through an app. I thought the task would take 2 hours. It took 8. Because the app takes a large percentage of the hourly rate, we negotiate a fair price and I paid in cash. It cost me less, and he had more money in his pocket for the same work
